trans-unit.source: Simulated hybrid cloud test environment | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Simulated hybrid cloud test environment | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Create a simulated hybrid cloud environment for IT pro or development testing, using two Azure virtual networks and a VNet-to-VNet connection.
trans-unit.target: Create a simulated hybrid cloud environment for IT pro or development testing, using two Azure virtual networks and a VNet-to-VNet connection.

trans-unit.source: Set up a simulated hybrid cloud environment for testing
trans-unit.target: Set up a simulated hybrid cloud environment for testing

trans-unit.source: This topic steps you through creating a simulated hybrid cloud environment with Microsoft Azure for testing using two separate Azure virtual networks.
trans-unit.target: This topic steps you through creating a simulated hybrid cloud environment with Microsoft Azure for testing using two separate Azure virtual networks.

trans-unit.source: Use this configuration as an alternative to
trans-unit.target: Use this configuration as an alternative to

trans-unit.source: [Set up a hybrid cloud environment for testing](virtual-networks-setup-hybrid-cloud-environment-testing.md) when you do not have a direct Internet connection and an available public IP address.
trans-unit.target: [Set up a hybrid cloud environment for testing](virtual-networks-setup-hybrid-cloud-environment-testing.md) when you do not have a direct Internet connection and an available public IP address.

trans-unit.source: Here is the resulting configuration.
trans-unit.target: Here is the resulting configuration.

trans-unit.source: This simulates a hybrid cloud production environment.
trans-unit.target: This simulates a hybrid cloud production environment.

trans-unit.source: It consists of:
trans-unit.target: It consists of:

trans-unit.source: A simulated and simplified on-premises network hosted in an Azure virtual network (the TestLab virtual network).
trans-unit.target: A simulated and simplified on-premises network hosted in an Azure virtual network (the TestLab virtual network).

trans-unit.source: A simulated cross-premises virtual network hosted in Azure (TestVNET).
trans-unit.target: A simulated cross-premises virtual network hosted in Azure (TestVNET).

trans-unit.source: A VNet-to-VNet connection between the two virtual networks.
trans-unit.target: A VNet-to-VNet connection between the two virtual networks.

trans-unit.source: A secondary domain controller in the TestVNET virtual network.
trans-unit.target: A secondary domain controller in the TestVNET virtual network.

trans-unit.source: This provides a basis and common starting point from which you can:
trans-unit.target: This provides a basis and common starting point from which you can:

trans-unit.source: Develop and test applications in a simulated hybrid cloud environment.
trans-unit.target: Develop and test applications in a simulated hybrid cloud environment.

trans-unit.source: Create test configurations of computers, some within the TestLab virtual network and some within the TestVNET virtual network, to simulate hybrid cloud-based IT workloads.
trans-unit.target: Create test configurations of computers, some within the TestLab virtual network and some within the TestVNET virtual network, to simulate hybrid cloud-based IT workloads.

trans-unit.source: There are four major phases to setting up this hybrid cloud test environment:
trans-unit.target: There are four major phases to setting up this hybrid cloud test environment:

trans-unit.source: Configure the TestLab virtual network.
trans-unit.target: Configure the TestLab virtual network.

trans-unit.source: Create the cross-premises virtual network.
trans-unit.target: Create the cross-premises virtual network.

trans-unit.source: Create the VNet-to-VNet VPN connection.
trans-unit.target: Create the VNet-to-VNet VPN connection.

trans-unit.source: Configure DC2.
trans-unit.target: Configure DC2.

trans-unit.source: If you don't already have an Azure subscription, you can sign up for a free trial at [Try Azure](http://azure.microsoft.com/pricing/free-trial/).
trans-unit.target: If you don't already have an Azure subscription, you can sign up for a free trial at [Try Azure](http://azure.microsoft.com/pricing/free-trial/).

trans-unit.source: If you have an MSDN Subscription, see [Azure benefit for MSDN subscribers](http://azure.microsoft.com/pricing/member-offers/msdn-benefits-details/).
trans-unit.target: If you have an MSDN Subscription, see [Azure benefit for MSDN subscribers](http://azure.microsoft.com/pricing/member-offers/msdn-benefits-details/).

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] Virtual machines and virtual network gateways in Azure incur an ongoing monetary cost when they are running.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] Virtual machines and virtual network gateways in Azure incur an ongoing monetary cost when they are running.

trans-unit.source: This cost is billed against your free trial, MSDN subscription, or paid subscription.
trans-unit.target: This cost is billed against your free trial, MSDN subscription, or paid subscription.

trans-unit.source: To reduce the costs of running this test environment when you are not using it, see [Minimizing the ongoing costs of this environment](#costs) in this topic for more information.
trans-unit.target: To reduce the costs of running this test environment when you are not using it, see [Minimizing the ongoing costs of this environment](#costs) in this topic for more information.

trans-unit.source: Phase 1: Configure the TestLab virtual network
trans-unit.target: Phase 1: Configure the TestLab virtual network

trans-unit.source: Use the instructions in the [Base Configuration Test Environment](../virtual-machines/virtual-machines-base-configuration-test-environment.md) to configure the DC1, APP1, and CLIENT1 computers in an Azure virtual network named TestLab.
trans-unit.target: Use the instructions in the [Base Configuration Test Environment](../virtual-machines/virtual-machines-base-configuration-test-environment.md) to configure the DC1, APP1, and CLIENT1 computers in an Azure virtual network named TestLab.

trans-unit.source: From the Azure Management Portal on your local computer, connect to DC1 with the CORP\User1 credentials.
trans-unit.target: From the Azure Management Portal on your local computer, connect to DC1 with the CORP\User1 credentials.

trans-unit.source: To configure the CORP domain so that computers and users use their local domain controller for authentication, run these commands from an administrator-level Windows PowerShell command prompt.
trans-unit.target: To configure the CORP domain so that computers and users use their local domain controller for authentication, run these commands from an administrator-level Windows PowerShell command prompt.

trans-unit.source: This is your current configuration.
trans-unit.target: This is your current configuration.

trans-unit.source: Phase 2: Create the TestVNET virtual network
trans-unit.target: Phase 2: Create the TestVNET virtual network

trans-unit.source: First, create a new virtual network named TestVNET.
trans-unit.target: First, create a new virtual network named TestVNET.

trans-unit.source: In the task bar of the Azure Management Portal, click **New > Network Services > Virtual Network > Custom Create**.
trans-unit.target: In the task bar of the Azure Management Portal, click **New > Network Services > Virtual Network > Custom Create**.

trans-unit.source: On the Virtual Network Details page, type **TestVNET** in **Name**.
trans-unit.target: On the Virtual Network Details page, type **TestVNET** in **Name**.

trans-unit.source: In **Location**, select the appropriate location.
trans-unit.target: In **Location**, select the appropriate location.

trans-unit.source: Click the Next arrow.
trans-unit.target: Click the Next arrow.

trans-unit.source: On the DNS Servers and VPN Connectivity page, in **DNS Servers**, type **DC1** in **Select or enter name**, and then click the Next arrow.
trans-unit.target: On the DNS Servers and VPN Connectivity page, in **DNS Servers**, type **DC1** in **Select or enter name**, and then click the Next arrow.

trans-unit.source: On the Virtual Network Address Spaces page:
trans-unit.target: On the Virtual Network Address Spaces page:

trans-unit.source: In **Address Space**, in **Starting IP**, select or type **192.168.0.0**.
trans-unit.target: In **Address Space**, in **Starting IP**, select or type **192.168.0.0**.

trans-unit.source: In **Subnets**, click **Subnet-1** and replace the name with **TestSubnet**.
trans-unit.target: In **Subnets**, click **Subnet-1** and replace the name with **TestSubnet**.

trans-unit.source: In the **CIDR (Address Count)** column for the TestSubnet, click **/24 (256)**.
trans-unit.target: In the **CIDR (Address Count)** column for the TestSubnet, click **/24 (256)**.

trans-unit.source: Click the Complete icon.
trans-unit.target: Click the Complete icon.

trans-unit.source: Wait until the virtual network is created before continuing.
trans-unit.target: Wait until the virtual network is created before continuing.

trans-unit.source: Next, use the instructions in [How to install and configure Azure PowerShell to install Azure PowerShell on your local computer](../install-configure-powershell.md).
trans-unit.target: Next, use the instructions in [How to install and configure Azure PowerShell to install Azure PowerShell on your local computer](../install-configure-powershell.md).

trans-unit.source: Next, create a new cloud service for the TestVNET virtual network.
trans-unit.target: Next, create a new cloud service for the TestVNET virtual network.

trans-unit.source: You must pick a unique name.
trans-unit.target: You must pick a unique name.

trans-unit.source: For example, you could name it **TestVNET-***UniqueSequence*, in which *UniqueSequence* is an abbreviation of your organization.
trans-unit.target: For example, you could name it **TestVNET-***UniqueSequence*, in which *UniqueSequence* is an abbreviation of your organization.

trans-unit.source: For example, if your organization is named Tailspin Toys, you could name the cloud service **TestVNET-Tailspin**.
trans-unit.target: For example, if your organization is named Tailspin Toys, you could name the cloud service **TestVNET-Tailspin**.

trans-unit.source: You can test for the uniqueness of the name with this Azure PowerShell command on your local computer.
trans-unit.target: You can test for the uniqueness of the name with this Azure PowerShell command on your local computer.

trans-unit.source: If this command returns "False", your proposed name is unique.
trans-unit.target: If this command returns "False", your proposed name is unique.

trans-unit.source: Create the cloud service with this command.
trans-unit.target: Create the cloud service with this command.

trans-unit.source: This is your current configuration.
trans-unit.target: This is your current configuration.

trans-unit.source: Phase 3: Create the VNet-to-VNet connection
trans-unit.target: Phase 3: Create the VNet-to-VNet connection

trans-unit.source: First, you create local networks that represent the address space of each virtual network.
trans-unit.target: First, you create local networks that represent the address space of each virtual network.

trans-unit.source: From the Azure Management Portal on your local computer, click **New > Network Services > Virtual Network > Add Local Network**.
trans-unit.target: From the Azure Management Portal on your local computer, click **New > Network Services > Virtual Network > Add Local Network**.

trans-unit.source: On the Specify your local network details page, type **TestLabLNet** in **Name**, type **131.107.0.1** in **VPN Device IP Address**, and then click the right arrow.
trans-unit.target: On the Specify your local network details page, type **TestLabLNet** in **Name**, type **131.107.0.1** in **VPN Device IP Address**, and then click the right arrow.

trans-unit.source: On the Specify the address space page, in **Starting I**P, type **10.0.0.0**.
trans-unit.target: On the Specify the address space page, in **Starting I**P, type **10.0.0.0**.

trans-unit.source: In **CIDR (Address Count)**, select **/24 (256)**, and then click the check mark.
trans-unit.target: In **CIDR (Address Count)**, select **/24 (256)**, and then click the check mark.

trans-unit.source: Click **New > Network Services > Virtual Network > Add Local Network**.
trans-unit.target: Click **New > Network Services > Virtual Network > Add Local Network**.

trans-unit.source: On the Specify your local network details page, type **TestVNETLNet** in **Name**, type **131.107.0.2** in **VPN Device IP Address**, and then click the right arrow.
trans-unit.target: On the Specify your local network details page, type **TestVNETLNet** in **Name**, type **131.107.0.2** in **VPN Device IP Address**, and then click the right arrow.

trans-unit.source: On the Specify the address space page, in **Starting IP**, type **192.168.0.0**.
trans-unit.target: On the Specify the address space page, in **Starting IP**, type **192.168.0.0**.

trans-unit.source: In **CIDR (Address Count)**, select **/24 (256)**, and then click the check mark.
trans-unit.target: In **CIDR (Address Count)**, select **/24 (256)**, and then click the check mark.

trans-unit.source: Note that the VPN device IP addresses of 131.107.0.1 and 131.107.0.2 are just temporary placeholder values until you configure gateways for the two virtual networks.
trans-unit.target: Note that the VPN device IP addresses of 131.107.0.1 and 131.107.0.2 are just temporary placeholder values until you configure gateways for the two virtual networks.

trans-unit.source: Next, you configure each virtual network to use a site-to-site VPN connection and the local network corresponding to the other virtual network.
trans-unit.target: Next, you configure each virtual network to use a site-to-site VPN connection and the local network corresponding to the other virtual network.

trans-unit.source: From the Azure Management Portal on your local computer, click **Networks** in the left pane, and then verify that the **Status** column for **TestLab** is set to **Created**.
trans-unit.target: From the Azure Management Portal on your local computer, click **Networks** in the left pane, and then verify that the **Status** column for **TestLab** is set to **Created**.

trans-unit.source: Click **TestLab**, and then click **Configure**.
trans-unit.target: Click **TestLab**, and then click **Configure**.

trans-unit.source: On the TestLab page, in the **Site-to-Site Connectivity** section, click **Connect to the local network**.
trans-unit.target: On the TestLab page, in the **Site-to-Site Connectivity** section, click **Connect to the local network**.

trans-unit.source: In **Local Network**, select **TestVNETLNet**.
trans-unit.target: In **Local Network**, select **TestVNETLNet**.

trans-unit.source: Click **Save** in the task bar.
trans-unit.target: Click **Save** in the task bar.

trans-unit.source: In some cases, you might need to click **Add Gateway Subnet** to create a subnet used by the Azure VPN gateway.
trans-unit.target: In some cases, you might need to click **Add Gateway Subnet** to create a subnet used by the Azure VPN gateway.

trans-unit.source: Click **Networks** in the left pane, and then verify that the **Status** column for TestVNET is set to **Created**.
trans-unit.target: Click **Networks** in the left pane, and then verify that the **Status** column for TestVNET is set to **Created**.

trans-unit.source: Click **TestVNET**, and then click **Configure**.
trans-unit.target: Click **TestVNET**, and then click **Configure**.

trans-unit.source: On the TestVNET page, in the **Site-to-Site Connectivity** section, click **Connect to the local network**.
trans-unit.target: On the TestVNET page, in the **Site-to-Site Connectivity** section, click **Connect to the local network**.

trans-unit.source: In **Local Network**, select **TestLabLNet**.
trans-unit.target: In **Local Network**, select **TestLabLNet**.

trans-unit.source: Click **Save** in the task bar.
trans-unit.target: Click **Save** in the task bar.

trans-unit.source: In some cases, you might need to click **Add Gateway Subnet** to create a subnet used by the Azure VPN gateway.
trans-unit.target: In some cases, you might need to click **Add Gateway Subnet** to create a subnet used by the Azure VPN gateway.

trans-unit.source: Next, you create virtual network gateways for the two virtual networks.
trans-unit.target: Next, you create virtual network gateways for the two virtual networks.

trans-unit.source: From the Azure Management Portal, on the **Networks** page, click **TestLab**.
trans-unit.target: From the Azure Management Portal, on the **Networks** page, click **TestLab**.

trans-unit.source: On the Dashboard page, you should see a status of **The Gateway Was Not Created**.
trans-unit.target: On the Dashboard page, you should see a status of **The Gateway Was Not Created**.

trans-unit.source: In the task bar, click **Create Gateway**, and then click **Dynamic Routing**.
trans-unit.target: In the task bar, click **Create Gateway**, and then click **Dynamic Routing**.

trans-unit.source: Click **Yes** when prompted.
trans-unit.target: Click **Yes** when prompted.

trans-unit.source: Wait until the gateway is complete and its status changes to **Connecting**.
trans-unit.target: Wait until the gateway is complete and its status changes to **Connecting**.

trans-unit.source: This could take a few minutes.
trans-unit.target: This could take a few minutes.

trans-unit.source: From the Dashboard page, note the **Gateway IP Address**.
trans-unit.target: From the Dashboard page, note the **Gateway IP Address**.

trans-unit.source: This is the public IP address of the Azure VPN gateway for the TestLab virtual network.
trans-unit.target: This is the public IP address of the Azure VPN gateway for the TestLab virtual network.

trans-unit.source: Record this IP address, as you will need this to configure the VNet-to-VNet connection.
trans-unit.target: Record this IP address, as you will need this to configure the VNet-to-VNet connection.

trans-unit.source: In the task bar, click **Manage Key**, and the click the copy icon next to the key to copy it to your clipboard.
trans-unit.target: In the task bar, click **Manage Key**, and the click the copy icon next to the key to copy it to your clipboard.

trans-unit.source: Paste this key into a document and save it.
trans-unit.target: Paste this key into a document and save it.

trans-unit.source: You need this key value to configure the VNet-to-VNet connection.
trans-unit.target: You need this key value to configure the VNet-to-VNet connection.

trans-unit.source: On the Networks page, click **TestVNET**.
trans-unit.target: On the Networks page, click **TestVNET**.

trans-unit.source: On the Dashboard page, you should see a status of **The Gateway Was Not Created**.
trans-unit.target: On the Dashboard page, you should see a status of **The Gateway Was Not Created**.

trans-unit.source: In the task bar, click **Create Gateway**, and then click **Dynamic Routing**.
trans-unit.target: In the task bar, click **Create Gateway**, and then click **Dynamic Routing**.

trans-unit.source: Click **Yes** when prompted.
trans-unit.target: Click **Yes** when prompted.

trans-unit.source: Wait until the gateway is complete and its status changes to **Connecting**.
trans-unit.target: Wait until the gateway is complete and its status changes to **Connecting**.

trans-unit.source: This could take a few minutes.
trans-unit.target: This could take a few minutes.

trans-unit.source: From the Dashboard page, note the **Gateway IP Address**.
trans-unit.target: From the Dashboard page, note the **Gateway IP Address**.

trans-unit.source: This is the public IP address of the Azure VPN gateway for the TestVNET virtual network.
trans-unit.target: This is the public IP address of the Azure VPN gateway for the TestVNET virtual network.

trans-unit.source: Record this IP address, as you will need this to configure the VNet-to-VNet connection.
trans-unit.target: Record this IP address, as you will need this to configure the VNet-to-VNet connection.

trans-unit.source: Next, you configure the TestLabLNet and TestVNETLNet local networks with the public IP addresses obtained from creating the virtual network gateways.
trans-unit.target: Next, you configure the TestLabLNet and TestVNETLNet local networks with the public IP addresses obtained from creating the virtual network gateways.

trans-unit.source: From the Azure Management Portal, on the Networks page, click **Local Networks**.
trans-unit.target: From the Azure Management Portal, on the Networks page, click **Local Networks**.

trans-unit.source: Click **TestLabLNet**, and then click **Edit** in the task bar.
trans-unit.target: Click **TestLabLNet**, and then click **Edit** in the task bar.

trans-unit.source: On the Specify your local network details page, type the IP address of the virtual network gateway for the TestLab virtual network (from step 3 in the previous procedure) in **VPN Device IP Address (Optional)**, and then click the right arrow.
trans-unit.target: On the Specify your local network details page, type the IP address of the virtual network gateway for the TestLab virtual network (from step 3 in the previous procedure) in **VPN Device IP Address (Optional)**, and then click the right arrow.

trans-unit.source: On the Specify the address space page, click the check mark.
trans-unit.target: On the Specify the address space page, click the check mark.

trans-unit.source: On the Local Networks page, click **TestVNETLNet**, and then click **Edit** in the task bar.
trans-unit.target: On the Local Networks page, click **TestVNETLNet**, and then click **Edit** in the task bar.

trans-unit.source: On the Specify your local network details page, type the IP address of the virtual network gateway for the TestVNET virtual network (from step 7 in the previous procedure) in **VPN Device IP Address (Optional)**, and then click the right arrow.
trans-unit.target: On the Specify your local network details page, type the IP address of the virtual network gateway for the TestVNET virtual network (from step 7 in the previous procedure) in **VPN Device IP Address (Optional)**, and then click the right arrow.

trans-unit.source: On the Specify the address space page, click the check mark.
trans-unit.target: On the Specify the address space page, click the check mark.

trans-unit.source: Next, you will configure the pre-shared key for both gateways to use the same value, which is the key value determined by the Azure Management Portal for the TestLab virtual network.
trans-unit.target: Next, you will configure the pre-shared key for both gateways to use the same value, which is the key value determined by the Azure Management Portal for the TestLab virtual network.

trans-unit.source: Run these commands from an Azure PowerShell command prompt on your local computer, filling in the value of the TestLab pre-shared key.
trans-unit.target: Run these commands from an Azure PowerShell command prompt on your local computer, filling in the value of the TestLab pre-shared key.

trans-unit.source: Next, on the Network page of the Azure Management Portal on your local computer, click the **TestLab** virtual network, click **Dashboard**, and then click **Connect** in the task bar.
trans-unit.target: Next, on the Network page of the Azure Management Portal on your local computer, click the **TestLab** virtual network, click **Dashboard**, and then click **Connect** in the task bar.

trans-unit.source: Wait until the TestLab virtual network shows a connected state.
trans-unit.target: Wait until the TestLab virtual network shows a connected state.

trans-unit.source: This is your current configuration.
trans-unit.target: This is your current configuration.

trans-unit.source: Phase 4: Configure DC2
trans-unit.target: Phase 4: Configure DC2

trans-unit.source: First, create an Azure Virtual Machine for DC2.
trans-unit.target: First, create an Azure Virtual Machine for DC2.

trans-unit.source: Run these commands at the Azure PowerShell command prompt on your local computer.
trans-unit.target: Run these commands at the Azure PowerShell command prompt on your local computer.

trans-unit.source: Next, log on to the new DC2 virtual machine.
trans-unit.target: Next, log on to the new DC2 virtual machine.

trans-unit.source: In the left pane of the Azure Management Portal, click **Virtual Machines**, and then click **Running** in the **Status** column for DC2.
trans-unit.target: In the left pane of the Azure Management Portal, click **Virtual Machines**, and then click **Running** in the **Status** column for DC2.

trans-unit.source: In the task bar, click **Connect**.
trans-unit.target: In the task bar, click **Connect**.

trans-unit.source: When prompted to open DC2.rdp, click **Open**.
trans-unit.target: When prompted to open DC2.rdp, click **Open**.

trans-unit.source: When prompted with a Remote Desktop Connection message box, click **Connect**.
trans-unit.target: When prompted with a Remote Desktop Connection message box, click **Connect**.

trans-unit.source: When prompted for credentials, use these:
trans-unit.target: When prompted for credentials, use these:

trans-unit.source: Name: **DC2\\**[Local administrator account name]
trans-unit.target: Name: **DC2\\**[Local administrator account name]

trans-unit.source: Password: [Local administrator account password]
trans-unit.target: Password: [Local administrator account password]

trans-unit.source: When prompted with a Remote Desktop Connection message box referring to certificates, click **Yes**.
trans-unit.target: When prompted with a Remote Desktop Connection message box referring to certificates, click **Yes**.

trans-unit.source: Next, configure a Windows Firewall rule to allow traffic for basic connectivity testing.
trans-unit.target: Next, configure a Windows Firewall rule to allow traffic for basic connectivity testing.

trans-unit.source: From an administrator-level Windows PowerShell command prompt on DC2, run these commands.
trans-unit.target: From an administrator-level Windows PowerShell command prompt on DC2, run these commands.

trans-unit.source: The ping command should result in four successful replies from IP address 10.0.0.4.
trans-unit.target: The ping command should result in four successful replies from IP address 10.0.0.4.

trans-unit.source: This is a test of traffic across the Vnet-to-Vnet connection.
trans-unit.target: This is a test of traffic across the Vnet-to-Vnet connection.

trans-unit.source: Next, add the extra data disk as a new volume with the drive letter F:.
trans-unit.target: Next, add the extra data disk as a new volume with the drive letter F:.

trans-unit.source: In the left pane of Server Manager, click **File and Storage Services**, and then click **Disks**.
trans-unit.target: In the left pane of Server Manager, click **File and Storage Services**, and then click **Disks**.

trans-unit.source: In the contents pane, in the **Disks** group, click **disk 2** (with the **Partition** set to **Unknown**).
trans-unit.target: In the contents pane, in the **Disks** group, click **disk 2** (with the **Partition** set to **Unknown**).

trans-unit.source: Click **Tasks**, and then click **New Volume**.
trans-unit.target: Click **Tasks**, and then click **New Volume**.

trans-unit.source: On the Before you begin page of the New Volume Wizard, click **Next**.
trans-unit.target: On the Before you begin page of the New Volume Wizard, click **Next**.

trans-unit.source: On the Select the server and disk page, click **Disk 2**, and then click **Next**.
trans-unit.target: On the Select the server and disk page, click **Disk 2**, and then click **Next**.

trans-unit.source: When prompted, click **OK**.
trans-unit.target: When prompted, click **OK**.

trans-unit.source: On the Specify the size of the volume page, click **Next**.
trans-unit.target: On the Specify the size of the volume page, click **Next**.

trans-unit.source: On the Assign to a drive letter or folder page, click **Next**.
trans-unit.target: On the Assign to a drive letter or folder page, click **Next**.

trans-unit.source: On the Select file system settings page, click **Next**.
trans-unit.target: On the Select file system settings page, click **Next**.

trans-unit.source: On the Confirm selections page, click **Create**.
trans-unit.target: On the Confirm selections page, click **Create**.

trans-unit.source: When complete, click **Close**.
trans-unit.target: When complete, click **Close**.

trans-unit.source: Next, configure DC2 as a replica domain controller for the corp.contoso.com domain.
trans-unit.target: Next, configure DC2 as a replica domain controller for the corp.contoso.com domain.

trans-unit.source: Run these commands from the Windows PowerShell command prompt on DC2.
trans-unit.target: Run these commands from the Windows PowerShell command prompt on DC2.

trans-unit.source: Note that you are prompted to supply both the CORP\User1 password and a Directory Services Restore Mode (DSRM) password, and to restart DC2.
trans-unit.target: Note that you are prompted to supply both the CORP\User1 password and a Directory Services Restore Mode (DSRM) password, and to restart DC2.

trans-unit.source: Now that the TestVNET virtual network has its own DNS server (DC2), you must configure the TestVNET virtual network to use this DNS server.
trans-unit.target: Now that the TestVNET virtual network has its own DNS server (DC2), you must configure the TestVNET virtual network to use this DNS server.

trans-unit.source: In the left pane of the Azure Management Portal, click **Networks**, and then click **TestVNET**.
trans-unit.target: In the left pane of the Azure Management Portal, click **Networks**, and then click **TestVNET**.

trans-unit.source: Click **Configure**.
trans-unit.target: Click **Configure**.

trans-unit.source: In **DNS Servers**, remove the 10.0.0.4 entry.
trans-unit.target: In **DNS Servers**, remove the 10.0.0.4 entry.

trans-unit.source: In **DNS Servers**, add an entry with **DC2** as the name and **192.168.0.4** as the IP address.
trans-unit.target: In **DNS Servers**, add an entry with **DC2** as the name and **192.168.0.4** as the IP address.

trans-unit.source: In the command bar at the bottom, click **Save**, and then click **Yes** when prompted.
trans-unit.target: In the command bar at the bottom, click **Save**, and then click **Yes** when prompted.

trans-unit.source: Wait until the update to the TestVNet network is complete.
trans-unit.target: Wait until the update to the TestVNet network is complete.

trans-unit.source: This is your current configuration.
trans-unit.target: This is your current configuration.

trans-unit.source: Your simulated hybrid cloud environment is now ready for testing.
trans-unit.target: Your simulated hybrid cloud environment is now ready for testing.

trans-unit.source: You can also build these configurations in this test environment:
trans-unit.target: You can also build these configurations in this test environment:

trans-unit.source: SharePoint intranet farm
trans-unit.target: SharePoint intranet farm

trans-unit.source: Web-based LOB application
trans-unit.target: Web-based LOB application

trans-unit.source: Office 365 Directory Synchronization (DirSync) server
trans-unit.target: Office 365 Directory Synchronization (DirSync) server

trans-unit.source: Additional resources
trans-unit.target: Additional resources

trans-unit.source: Set up a hybrid cloud environment for testing
trans-unit.target: Set up a hybrid cloud environment for testing

trans-unit.source: Configure a VNet to VNet Connection
trans-unit.target: Configure a VNet to VNet Connection

trans-unit.source: Base Configuration Test Environment
trans-unit.target: Base Configuration Test Environment

trans-unit.source: Azure hybrid cloud test environments
trans-unit.target: Azure hybrid cloud test environments

trans-unit.source: Azure infrastructure services implementation guidelines
trans-unit.target: Azure infrastructure services implementation guidelines

trans-unit.source: Minimizing the ongoing costs of this environment
trans-unit.target: Minimizing the ongoing costs of this environment

trans-unit.source: To minimize the costs of running the virtual machines in this environment, perform your needed testing and demonstration as quickly as possible and then delete them or shut down the virtual machines when you are not using them.
trans-unit.target: To minimize the costs of running the virtual machines in this environment, perform your needed testing and demonstration as quickly as possible and then delete them or shut down the virtual machines when you are not using them.

trans-unit.source: For example, you could use Azure automation and a runbook to automatically shut down the virtual machines in the TestLab and Test_VNET virtual networks at the end of each business day.
trans-unit.target: For example, you could use Azure automation and a runbook to automatically shut down the virtual machines in the TestLab and Test_VNET virtual networks at the end of each business day.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see [Get started with Azure Automation](../automation-create-runbook-from-samples.md).
trans-unit.target: For more information, see [Get started with Azure Automation](../automation-create-runbook-from-samples.md).

trans-unit.source: When you start the virtual machines on the Corpnet subnet again, start DC1 first.
trans-unit.target: When you start the virtual machines on the Corpnet subnet again, start DC1 first.

trans-unit.source: An Azure VPN gateway is implemented as a set of two Azure virtual machines that incur an ongoing monetary cost.
trans-unit.target: An Azure VPN gateway is implemented as a set of two Azure virtual machines that incur an ongoing monetary cost.

trans-unit.source: For the details, see [Pricing - Virtual Network](http://azure.microsoft.com/pricing/details/virtual-network/).
trans-unit.target: For the details, see [Pricing - Virtual Network](http://azure.microsoft.com/pricing/details/virtual-network/).

trans-unit.source: To minimize the costs of the two VPN gateways (one for TestLab and one for TestVNET), create the test environment and perform your needed testing and demonstration as quickly as possible or delete the gateways with these steps.
trans-unit.target: To minimize the costs of the two VPN gateways (one for TestLab and one for TestVNET), create the test environment and perform your needed testing and demonstration as quickly as possible or delete the gateways with these steps.

trans-unit.source: From the Azure Management Portal on your local computer, click **Networks** in the left pane, click **TestLab**, and then click **Dashboard**.
trans-unit.target: From the Azure Management Portal on your local computer, click **Networks** in the left pane, click **TestLab**, and then click **Dashboard**.

trans-unit.source: In the task bar, click **Delete Gateway**.
trans-unit.target: In the task bar, click **Delete Gateway**.

trans-unit.source: Click **Yes** when prompted.
trans-unit.target: Click **Yes** when prompted.

trans-unit.source: Wait until the gateway is deleted and its status changes to **The Gateway Was Not Created**.
trans-unit.target: Wait until the gateway is deleted and its status changes to **The Gateway Was Not Created**.

trans-unit.source: Click **Networks** in the left pane, click **TestVNET**, and then click **Dashboard**.
trans-unit.target: Click **Networks** in the left pane, click **TestVNET**, and then click **Dashboard**.

trans-unit.source: In the task bar, click **Delete Gateway**.
trans-unit.target: In the task bar, click **Delete Gateway**.

trans-unit.source: Click **Yes** when prompted.
trans-unit.target: Click **Yes** when prompted.

trans-unit.source: Wait until the gateway is deleted and its status changes to **The Gateway Was Not Created**.
trans-unit.target: Wait until the gateway is deleted and its status changes to **The Gateway Was Not Created**.

trans-unit.source: If you delete the gateways and you want to restore this test environment, you must first create new gateways.
trans-unit.target: If you delete the gateways and you want to restore this test environment, you must first create new gateways.

trans-unit.source: From the Azure Management Portal on your local computer, click **Networks** in the left pane, and then click **TestLab**.
trans-unit.target: From the Azure Management Portal on your local computer, click **Networks** in the left pane, and then click **TestLab**.

trans-unit.source: On the Dashboard page, you should see a status of **The Gateway Was Not Created**.
trans-unit.target: On the Dashboard page, you should see a status of **The Gateway Was Not Created**.

trans-unit.source: In the task bar, click **Create Gateway**, and then click **Dynamic Routing**.
trans-unit.target: In the task bar, click **Create Gateway**, and then click **Dynamic Routing**.

trans-unit.source: Click **Yes** when prompted.
trans-unit.target: Click **Yes** when prompted.

trans-unit.source: Wait until the gateway is complete and its status changes to **Connecting**.
trans-unit.target: Wait until the gateway is complete and its status changes to **Connecting**.

trans-unit.source: This could take a few minutes.
trans-unit.target: This could take a few minutes.

trans-unit.source: From the Dashboard page, note the **Gateway IP Address**.
trans-unit.target: From the Dashboard page, note the **Gateway IP Address**.

trans-unit.source: This is the new public IP address of the Azure VPN gateway for the TestLab virtual network.
trans-unit.target: This is the new public IP address of the Azure VPN gateway for the TestLab virtual network.

trans-unit.source: You need this IP address to re-configure the TestLabLNet local network.
trans-unit.target: You need this IP address to re-configure the TestLabLNet local network.

trans-unit.source: In the task bar, click **Manage Key**, and then click the copy icon next to the key to copy it to your clipboard.
trans-unit.target: In the task bar, click **Manage Key**, and then click the copy icon next to the key to copy it to your clipboard.

trans-unit.source: Paste this key value into a document and save it.
trans-unit.target: Paste this key value into a document and save it.

trans-unit.source: You need this key value to re-configure the VPN gateway for the TestVNET virtual network.
trans-unit.target: You need this key value to re-configure the VPN gateway for the TestVNET virtual network.

trans-unit.source: From the Azure Management Portal on your local computer, click **Networks** in the left pane, and then click **TestVNET**.
trans-unit.target: From the Azure Management Portal on your local computer, click **Networks** in the left pane, and then click **TestVNET**.

trans-unit.source: On the Dashboard page, you should see a status of **The Gateway Was Not Created**.
trans-unit.target: On the Dashboard page, you should see a status of **The Gateway Was Not Created**.

trans-unit.source: In the task bar, click **Create Gateway**, and then click **Dynamic Routing**.
trans-unit.target: In the task bar, click **Create Gateway**, and then click **Dynamic Routing**.

trans-unit.source: Click **Yes** when prompted.
trans-unit.target: Click **Yes** when prompted.

trans-unit.source: Wait until the gateway is complete and its status changes to Connecting.
trans-unit.target: Wait until the gateway is complete and its status changes to Connecting.

trans-unit.source: This could take a few minutes.
trans-unit.target: This could take a few minutes.

trans-unit.source: From the Dashboard page, note the **Gateway IP Address**.
trans-unit.target: From the Dashboard page, note the **Gateway IP Address**.

trans-unit.source: This is the new public IP address of the Azure VPN gateway for the TestVNET virtual network.
trans-unit.target: This is the new public IP address of the Azure VPN gateway for the TestVNET virtual network.

trans-unit.source: You need this IP address to re-configure the TestVNETLNet local network.
trans-unit.target: You need this IP address to re-configure the TestVNETLNet local network.

trans-unit.source: Next, you configure the TestLabLNet and TestVNETLNet local networks with the new public IP addresses obtained from creating the virtual network gateways.
trans-unit.target: Next, you configure the TestLabLNet and TestVNETLNet local networks with the new public IP addresses obtained from creating the virtual network gateways.

trans-unit.source: From the Azure Management Portal, on the Networks page, click **Local Networks**.
trans-unit.target: From the Azure Management Portal, on the Networks page, click **Local Networks**.

trans-unit.source: Click **TestLabLNet**, and then click **Edit** in the task bar.
trans-unit.target: Click **TestLabLNet**, and then click **Edit** in the task bar.

trans-unit.source: On the Specify your local network details page, type the IP address of the virtual network gateway for the TestLab virtual network (from step 3 in the previous procedure) in **VPN Device IP Address (Optional)**, and then click the right arrow.
trans-unit.target: On the Specify your local network details page, type the IP address of the virtual network gateway for the TestLab virtual network (from step 3 in the previous procedure) in **VPN Device IP Address (Optional)**, and then click the right arrow.

trans-unit.source: On the Specify the address space page, click the check mark.
trans-unit.target: On the Specify the address space page, click the check mark.

trans-unit.source: On the Local Networks page, click **TestVNETLNet**, and then click **Edit** in the task bar.
trans-unit.target: On the Local Networks page, click **TestVNETLNet**, and then click **Edit** in the task bar.

trans-unit.source: On the Specify your local network details page, type the IP address of the virtual network gateway for the TestVNET virtual network (from step 7 in the previous procedure) in **VPN Device IP Address (Optional)**, and then click the right arrow.
trans-unit.target: On the Specify your local network details page, type the IP address of the virtual network gateway for the TestVNET virtual network (from step 7 in the previous procedure) in **VPN Device IP Address (Optional)**, and then click the right arrow.

trans-unit.source: On the Specify the address space page, click the check mark.
trans-unit.target: On the Specify the address space page, click the check mark.

trans-unit.source: Next, you configure the pre-shared key for both gateways to use the same value, which is the key value determined by the Azure Management Portal for the TestLab virtual network.
trans-unit.target: Next, you configure the pre-shared key for both gateways to use the same value, which is the key value determined by the Azure Management Portal for the TestLab virtual network.

trans-unit.source: Run these commands from an Azure PowerShell command prompt on your local computer, filling in the value of the TestLab pre-shared key.
trans-unit.target: Run these commands from an Azure PowerShell command prompt on your local computer, filling in the value of the TestLab pre-shared key.

trans-unit.source: Next, on the Network page of the Azure Management Portal, click the **TestLab** virtual network, and then click **Connect** in the task bar.
trans-unit.target: Next, on the Network page of the Azure Management Portal, click the **TestLab** virtual network, and then click **Connect** in the task bar.

trans-unit.source: Wait until the TestLab virtual network shows a connected state to the TestVNET local network.
trans-unit.target: Wait until the TestLab virtual network shows a connected state to the TestVNET local network.
